captions.text:
Ah, Ninja Gaiden. How long&#39;s it been since our 
last ninj? Thirteen years! 2012 was when I last

did a Ninja Gaiden game, namely Ninja Gaiden 3, 
a game about a ninja flipping out and killing

people. And, er... possibly some other things. 
Actually, I don&#39;t remember anything else. Oh,

I think there was a lady with big knockers 
flapping about. Although for the era,

that&#39;s like remembering that the title had 
consonants in it. Huh. You know, I think I

might have hit upon why we haven&#39;t heard much 
from Ninja Gaiden lately. It&#39;s because there&#39;s

not a whole lot you can do with the material. 
A ninja flips out and kills people. Yeah,

that&#39;s what ninjas fucking do. It&#39;s like 
making a game about the tide going in and

out. Call me when it&#39;s about a ninja learning 
to make sourdough or applying for jobseeker&#39;s

allowance. Perhaps in recognition of the 
concept&#39;s essential lack of room for growth,

Koei Tecmo have opted to go the route of making a 
pixel art, retro-style 2D game harkening back to

old classic Ninja Gaidens from the 8-bit era, 
the way one would say to a stubborn teenager,

&quot;Fine, stay in your room and play with your 
toys, and come down to the dinner table when

you&#39;re ready to be part of this family and 
get some fucking HD graphics down you.&quot;

In Ninja Gaiden: Ragebound, we play as Kenji, a 
junior executive murderer at the Hayabusa ninja

clan, who are nice, honorable murderers who always 
put a comfy pillow on the floor before they murder

a dude, and after evil demons from hell invade the 
world &#39;cause they&#39;ve got literally fuck all else

on, Kenji gets his rice balls pushed in by demons 
and is forced to combine his powers with Kumori,

a bad bitch lady ninja from a rival, evil ninja 
clan called the Black Spiders who are bad and

untrustworthy because they treat murder for 
hire like it&#39;s some kind of crime. Anyway,

by absorbing the powers of Kumori, Kenji 
augments his stabbing ability with the secret

forbidden knowledge of—brace yourself—throwing 
knives. Er... I ain&#39;t ragging on you, Kenji,

but could you not have learned to chuck knives 
without leasing your body to the soul of an evil

lady ninja? What, were the Black Spider Clan 
patent squatting on the concept of whanging

shit about? Or is this some Hayabusa Clan thing, 
like throwing knives are cheating and it&#39;s only

honorable to stab a guy if you&#39;re close enough 
to give him a reassuring kiss on the cheek?

Anyway, Kenji and Kumori set out to turn back the 
demon invasion despite their mutual distrust and

hatred, and the character arc between them as 
the game unfolds is exactly what you&#39;d expect,

really. But it&#39;s not a particularly long game, 
and the dialogue scenes are brief and spaced

out to not interrupt the arcade action too 
much, so they have to go through the speed

version of this particular dynamic. Hate, 
hate, bicker, bicker, tease, tease, sarcasm,

humor, achieve mutual goals, newfound respect, 
sacrifice for the other, romance, kissy kissy,

lots of ninja clan hybrid babies who can stab with 
swords and then throw the swords at people. So,

as I say, it&#39;s a very old-school arcade 
level-based 2D platformer: go through themed

environment doing platform puzzles and slitting 
up the cannon fodder; big boss fight at the end;

onto next level. And to skip to the summary for 
a moment, I rather enjoyed it. I hate fast-paced

hack-and-slash games where they keep giving you 
more and more combos you have to remember. Oh,

press X X X X Y Y to do the Graceful Swan Buttock 
Targeting Mule Kick, when 90% of the time,

you can get as far as X X and then have to 
dodge out of the way again &#39;cause the other

dude&#39;s swinging the decommissioned sea mine 
on the end of a lamppost he carries around.

Well, Ragebound ain&#39;t got none of that shite. 
Here&#39;s the rundown on Kenji&#39;s attack controls:

press sword button; whatever is in front of 
you dies. Then Kenji merges with Kumori and

you acquire the ability to press fling knife 
button; anything on the same lateral plane as

you dies. Most enemies die in one hit except 
for the big ones, which die in one hit if you

charged a super-powered big bollocks attack from 
killing specific other enemies first, so building

up combos is more about picking off targets 
in the most optimal order, and it makes for

a banging-ass, fast-paced core gameplay loop; all 
the fun of ninja flipouts with a spicy seasoning

of data validation. The platforming I&#39;m less keen 
on; I wish it wouldn&#39;t kill you for falling off

the screen. Come on, Ninja Gaiden, be cool. Just 
teleport us back onto the ledge with a little

health penalty; every other game does that these 
days. &quot;I don&#39;t care what mummy says; do what daddy

says. Back to the checkpoint. You just failed the 
bonus objective to not fall down any pits, by the

way, to add an extra scent-marking tiger incident 
to your shame safari.&quot; But on the whole, it&#39;s a

strong primary gameplay loop, and as you should 
know by now, that&#39;s all I need to recommend it.

Although it wouldn&#39;t be modern game design 
if they didn&#39;t try to gild the lily,

so of course there&#39;s an upgrade shop where you 
spend hidden collectibles on equippable talismans

and shit. I ended up equipping the first two 
talismans I got and kept them for the whole game,

so whoops, that&#39;s my entire incentive to hunt for 
collectibles pissed up the fucking wall. Oh, wait,

I did buy that one special attack that gives you 
a free heal, but again, only used that and bought

nothing else for the whole game. &#39;Cause I bloody 
needed it; the game hands out health pickups with

the speed and efficiency of a fucking bitcoin 
mining rig. But even so, I was surprised by how

easy I found the game. I breezed through the whole 
thing in more or less one session. Can this really

be the notoriously hard Ninja Gaiden franchise? 
Isn&#39;t this the point where you&#39;re supposed to be

going at my dainty arse like a Lernaean Hydra 
bobbing for apples? No, I completed the game.

But after a fairly archetypal Endingtron 3000 
situation with the usual result of me reloading

a save to see how the other ending goes, I smelt 
a little ninja rat. &quot;Hey. I&#39;ve played enough

Castlevania and Persona games to know what is and 
is not a &#39;real&#39; ending. Where&#39;s the deliriously

happy canon ending where all our friends 
cheer us on while we fight a dude in space?&quot;

One swift Google later, I found—oh, hang on, I 
forgot the spoiler alert. SPOILER ALERT. SPOILER

ALERT. IT&#39;LL REALLY HURT TO HEAR THE DIRT IF WITH 
THIS GAME YOU INTEND TO FLIRT, SO LET ME ASSERT:

SPOILER ALERT. Google said, &quot;To get the True 
Ending, first play through the game on hard

mode—&quot; OH, YOU SNEAKY LITTLE RACCOON, Ninja 
Gaiden: Ragebound. First taste&#39;s free, is it?

Make me play through on easy first, lure me in 
with your fun graphics and cool gameplay and then

out come the great big knobbly decommissioned sea 
mines? Well, it kind of worked. Unusually for me,

I did restart the game on hard and was further 
impressed that hard mode actually adds more

enemies and hazards instead of the usual &quot;crank 
up all the damage numbers and call it a day.&quot;

In short, it soon became clear that hard mode 
is a case of &quot;The Real Ninja Gaiden: Ragebound

starts here.&quot; I do appreciate it for letting 
story-focused players get their nice, gentle

cuddle session in before the game brings out the 
nipple clamps for the hardcore audience, and I was

enjoying the hard mode run until the boss fights 
started really taking the piss, at which point

I thought to go back to Google to learn exactly 
what getting the True Ending was gonna ask of me,

and well... Entire game boss rush? On ONE health 
bar? Fuck off, Ninja Gaiden! I&#39;m not made of ninj.
